data.text:
What is Titanium Dioxide?

Titanium Dioxide is an industrial chemical made up of the elements titanium and oxygen. Titanium Dioxide is also known as Titania and its chemical formula is TiO2. It is a white powder that is tasteless and odorless. It comes in the forms:

Rutile Titanium Dioxide 94% (Sulfate R-298)

Rutile Titanium Dioxide (Sulfate R-248)

Titanium Oxide Rutile Pigment CR-350 (Chloride)

This chemical has many industrial uses, but it is most commonly used in paints and varnishes.

Titanium Dioxide Uses

Titanium Dioxide is an extremely useful chemical. It is a special use chemical most popularly used in paints and varnishes. Its uses are:

as a pigment in paints, coatings, plastics, papers, inks, foods, medicines, and most toothpastes;

in fibers;

in the making of cosmetics products;

the production of pure titanium;

in the manufacturing of glass and glass ceramics;

n chemical processes as a catalyst and chemical intermediate.

As a thin film for excellent reflective optical coating for dielectric mirrors.

Making decorative thin films.

in the making of a pearlescent pigment called Iriodin.

as sunscreens and UV blocking pigments in cosmetics and skincare products.

As a sunscreen it is very effective because it lowers the risk of sunburns and problems associated with excessive long-term exposure to the sun.

in ceramic glazes as an opacifier.

It is also used as a tattoo pigment and in styptic pencils.

in the food industry as a whitener and smoother. It gives the food a fresh and appealing look.

Is Titanium Dioxide Safe?

Titanium Dioxide is generally considered unsafe because the chemical is toxic. Exposure to this chemical can have acute health effects. According to the MSDS of Titanium Dioxide 94% (Sulfate R-298), MSDS of Titanium Dioxide (Sulfate R-248), and MSDS of Titanium Oxide Rutile Pigment CR-350 (Chloride) it can cause mild eye irritation. It may be absorbed through the skin and cause mild skin irritation. It can be very harmful if ingested because it may cause digestive tract irritation, pain constipation, or diarrhea. It may also cause ataxia, increased blood pressure, hallucinations, hyper-motility, muscle contraction/spasticity, fatigue, psychosis and tremors. Furthermore, it may also cause respiratory tract irritation. Proper storage and disposal of Titanium Dioxide needs to be taken into consideration in order to avoid any unwanted effects.

How is Titanium Dioxide Made?

Industrially, Titanium Dioxide is made by the mineral ilmenite. Ilmenite is converted to pigment grade titanium dioxide by chloride or sulfate process. The sulfate process includes treatment of ilmenite with sulfuric acid. The product is then further processed according to the requirements.

In the chloride process the ilmenite reacts with elemental chlorine. This converts ilmenite to titanium tetrachloride. This is then distilled and reacts with oxygen to produce titanium dioxide.
